titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jay Blotcher Papers MSS.137
titlestmt.author: Processed by Jessica Shimmin, July 2003.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from blotcher.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-12-04 15:48:30 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

change.item: Updated by Natalia Medero to state that some audiovisual materials have been digitized and are accessible to patrons.

physdesc.extent: in 2 record cartons, 2 card boxes, and 1 flat box.

did.abstract: Jay Blotcher represented the lives of gay and lesbian people through his work as a journalist, publicist, freelance writer, film producer and activist. The Jay Blotcher Papers contain print, media, ephemera, and clothing materials documenting the Lesbian and Gay Rights Movement, AIDS activism and queer activism in the 1990s. The collection includes media releases and other publicity for ACT UP and Queer Nation, two major AIDS and queer advocacy organizations as well as the Anti-Violence Campaign, The American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR), and several smaller organizations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Jay Blotcher in May 2003. The accession number associated with this gift is 2003.137.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jay Blotcher represented the lives of gays and lesbians through his work as a journalist, publicist, freelance writer, film producer, and activist. His earliest work on queer activism was a feature on the Gay Student Organization in his college newspaper, The Daily Orange. Blotcher produced work on The American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR), Michelangelo Signorile and numerous other individuals and grassroots organizations. In 1987, he joined ACT UP New York, represented the group at the International AIDS Conferences in Montreal, Amsterdam and Yokohama, and served as Media Coordinator for the organization from 1989-1990. Blotcher was also a founding member and Media Coordinator for Queer Nation New York, and the executive producer of the Anti-Violence Campaign. He was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS activism and queer activism in New York and internationally, both as a professional and as an activist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jay Blotcher Papers (1987-2001) contain print materials, media, ephemera and clothing documenting the Lesbian and Gay Rights Movement, HIV/AIDS Activism and Queer Activism in the 1990s. The collection includes media releases and other publicity for ACT UP and Queer Nation, two major AIDS and queer advocacy organizations as well as the Anti-Violence Campaign, The American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR), and several smaller organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into four series:
Series I: Files and Printed Materials;
Where possible, the collection retains Jay Blotcher's own organization. Materials in Series I: Printed Materials are arranged alphabetically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at Fales Library and Special Collections

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Select periodicals have been separated from the collection and cataloged individually in Bobcat: "Lisp" periodical, 1995.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Suggested format for citing materials in a collection: Identification of item, date; Jay Blotcher Papers; MSS 137; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact NYU Special Collections (special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596) with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to some audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.

Audiovisual materials that have not been preserved may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact NYU Special Collections (special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596) with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions regarding arrangement, description, and physical interventions for this collection prior to 2025 are unknown.

did.unittitle: Series I: Files and Printed Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains clippings, press releases and typescripts relating to Jay Botcher's work as Media Coordinator for ACT UP and Queer Nation as well as materials relating to his work as a publicist for gay and lesbian authors and organizations from 1987-2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Audio cassettes, microcassettes, floppy disks and videocassettes containing articles, interviews, music and programs relating to Jay Blotcher's activism and interests.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual and born-digital materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Adoption ban for gays ruled unconstitutional in Sarasota; Florida lawmaker from Davie withdraws civil rights bill; Navy claims gay sailor was murdered by gay ex-lover; California city legally defines 'family'; This gay in history did it on stage: Colin Higgins; A report on gay women in the military; Making an artistic statement: art about AIDS; To buy or not to buy: that is the question of boycotts; Music: Hosework! and Dykes!!"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials including pins, nametags, pens and magnets relating to Jay Blotcher's activism and professional work for Queer Nation, ACT UP and the Lesbian and Gay rights movement.

did.unittitle: Square button. "ACT UP Fight Back Fight AIDS"
Circular button, missing pin. "Try 31. For a Change. WNYC-TV" Paper pink triangle with words "our time" pasted on.
Rectangular button. "Rainbow Run for the End of AIDS San Francisco to Vancouver. June 7th-August 4th 1990. In Honor of Tom Waddell and Keith Haring."
Circular button. [Trans activist, Marsha P. Johnson]
Rectangular sticker. "PM Chretien We're Dying for a National AIDS Strategy"
Postcard from the Beverly Prescott hotel. " 'When a shower just won't do' The Beverly Prescott's King Jacuzzi Room"
Rectangular Magnet. "The Pants Too? Yes, Please Donate. Out of the closet thrift store and AIDS healthcare foundation."
XI International Conference on AIDS nametag. "Jay Blotcher- The Front Page" With Durex pen.
Necklace. One side "ACT UP for a cure" Opposite side "1992 March on Washington for Lesbian, Gay and Bi Equal Rights and Liberation."
One pencil. " 'Pageant' - NY's Nightly Beauty Contest"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains t-shirts and a sweatshirt related to Jay Blotcher's professional career, activism and interests. All of series IV is located in Box 5, which is an OVERSIZE box.

did.unittitle: T-shirt. "Some of my best friends are Queer in America"
Sweatshirt. "Queer Nation get used to it!"
